Question_1.Context: Biliverdin is a bile pigment that is produced through the degradation of heme, a component of hemoglobin in red blood cells.
Question_1.Question: What enzyme is responsible for the selective cleavage of heme to produce biliverdin?
Question_1.Source: A selective cleavage of heme by heme oxygenase (HO; EC 1.14.99.3) occurs at the α-methane bridge, producing the biliverdin IXα isomer.

Question_2.Context: Biliverdin can be reduced to another compound that is also part of heme metabolism in vertebrates.
Question_2.Question: What is biliverdin reduced to in the human body?
Question_2.Source: Biliverdin is subsequently reduced to bilirubin IXα by biliverdin reductase (EC 1.3.1.24).

Question_3.Context: There are different types of heme oxygenase (HO) enzymes, each with varying functions and characteristics.
Question_3.Question: Which type of heme oxygenase has the highest catalytic activity towards heme?
Question_3.Source: Among them, HO1 has the highest catalytic activity towards heme and belongs to the heat shock protein family.

Question_4.Context: Biliverdin has been found to have multiple therapeutic effects on the human body.
Question_4.Question: Which of the following is NOT a therapeutic effect of biliverdin?
Question_4.Source: However, recent studies have revealed that it has many therapeutic effects on the human body, including antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties, suppression of the immune response.

Question_5.Context: Biliverdin has applications beyond its therapeutic effects, including its use in materials science.
Question_5.Question: What is one of the significant applications of biliverdin in the field of materials science?
Question_5.A: As a catalyst for chemical reactions
Question_5.B: As a chromophore for certain materials
Question_5.C: As a preservative for biological samples
Question_5.D: As a solvent for organic compounds
Question_5.Source: Additionally, biliverdin can also serve as a chromophore for certain materials.

Question_6.Context: Biliverdin is naturally present in various biological materials across different species.
Question_6.Question: Which of the following is NOT a natural source of biliverdin?
Question_6.Source: Biliverdin naturally exists in bird eggshells and bile, as well as in fish blood and bile.

Question_7.Context: The production of biliverdin can be achieved through the biotransformation of heme using biological processes.
Question_7.Question: What is the immediate precursor of biliverdin in the biotransformation process?
Question_7.Source: Heme is the immediate precursor of biliverdin and can be extracted in large quantities from animal blood at low cost.

Question_8.Context: Chemical hydrolysis and biotransformation are two methods that can be used to convert heme into biliverdin.
Question_8.Question: What is a disadvantage of using chemical hydrolysis to produce biliverdin from heme?
Question_8.B: It has no stereoselectivity and yields four isomers of biliverdin
Question_8.D: It is a very rapid process
Question_8.Source: Chemical hydrolysis has no stereoselectivity and yields four isomers of biliverdin (IXα, IXβ, IXγ, and IXδ).

Question_9.Context: In the context of biotransformation, the efficiency of converting heme into biliverdin can be affected by the characteristics of the host organism.
Question_9.Question: Why is it challenging for E. coli cells to achieve a high yield of biliverdin through biotransformation?
Question_9.A: E. coli cells cannot synthesize heme
Question_9.B: E. coli cells have a high rate of biliverdin degradation
Question_9.C: E. coli cells cannot take up exogenous heme due to the absence of carrier proteins in its cell membranes
Question_9.D: E. coli cells lack the necessary enzymes for biotransformation
Question_9.Source: However, due to the limited ability of E. coli to synthesize heme, achieving a high yield of biliverdin by this route is challenging.

Question_10.Context: The use of recombinant yeast cells has been explored for the biotransformation of heme into biliverdin.
Question_10.Question: What is an advantage of using yeast cells over E. coli for the uptake of exogenous heme?
Question_10.A: Yeast cells have a higher metabolic rate
Question_10.B: Yeast cells can take up exogenous heme
Question_10.D: Yeast cells do not require oxygen for biotransformation
Question_10.Source: Unlike E. coli, yeast cells can take up exogenous heme.
